thread.title: American Airlines, Southwest Airlines: No collusion here
thread.title_full: American Airlines, Southwest Airlines: No collusion here

author: Bill Hethcock
title: American Airlines, Southwest Airlines: No collusion here
text:
See All Bizspace Properties “There has been no illegal behavior on the part of American Airlines,” Parker told employees in the letter. “We will comply fully with the demands of the (investigation) and this fact will be proven.” Brad Hawkins, a spokesman for Southwest (NYSE: LUV), sent an email to the Dallas Business Journal saying the airline would “fully cooperate, of course, in answering any questions.” The Justice Department sent “civil investigation demand” letters, similar to subpoenas, to several U.S. airlines this week asking the carriers to provide all documents pertaining to how they decide available seats and flights they will operate and whether they are talking to each other about capacity. Parker’s letter said American’s capacity has grown faster than demand in recent years, leading to fares actually falling. The CEO went on to tell employees that the airline does not know what prompted the investigation but speculates that it could be recent public comments about aircraft capacity. Parker and other airline chief executives discussed capacity — limiting flights and seats — at a meeting of the International Air Transport Association in early June in Miami. Parker said the airlines had learned from past price wars that increasing capacity too fast can lead to lower ticket prices and slimmer profit margins. Atlanta-based Delta Air Lines and Chicago-based United Airlines are also part of the Justice Department investigation into “possible unlawful coordination.” Supporters of the collusion probe say the four largest U.S. carriers now control 80 percent of the market. They note that airline fares didn’t change much even when jet fuel prices dropped by 24 percent last year and that every flight seems booked to capacity to the point of passenger discomfort. Airline officials, including Parker, have countered that they have a duty to maximize capacity to maximize profits for shareholders. The investigation came about two weeks after Connecticut Sen. Richard Blumenthal wrote to the Justice Department asking for a probe of possible collusion. To prove that U.S. airlines actually colluded, the Justice Department must show that the airlines illegally communicated with the intent to reduce competition, and that the illegal communications had the desired effect.
